learning_outcomes.outcome: Define sustainability and identify its three core pillars: environmental, economic, and social.
Explain the principles of sustainable development and their relevance to global challenges.
Demonstrate sustainable practices in real-world contexts such as energy use, waste reduction, or transportation.
Compare the impact of unsustainable practices across different industries and ecosystems.
Assess current policies and strategies for promoting sustainability in a chosen domain.
Design a sustainability action plan or campaign that addresses local or global environmental issues.
List foundational concepts and terminologies related to Generative AI and neural networks.
Describe how transformer-based models like GPT, BERT, and DALL·E function and generate content.
Utilize GenAI tools for generating content, such as text, images, or code, based on given prompts.
Differentiate between traditional AI and GenAI in terms of architecture, output quality, and use cases.
Critically assess the ethical considerations of using GenAI, including bias, data privacy, and misinformation.
Develop a personalized learning roadmap or a GenAI-based application prototype that solves a real-world problem.
Recall fundamental principles of thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, mechanics of materials, and machine design.
Explain how mechanical systems such as engines, pumps, and HVAC systems operate using core engineering principles.
Solve real-world problems using mechanical engineering tools and methods, including CAD, FEA, and thermal simulations.
Break down the behavior of mechanical systems under various loads, stresses, and thermal conditions to identify failure modes or inefficiencies.
Assess the performance, sustainability, and cost-effectiveness of engineering solutions and designs.
Design and prototype an innovative mechanical system or component to address a specific engineering challenge.
Recall key concepts and terminology in structural analysis, geotechnical engineering, transportation, and construction materials.
Describe how different civil engineering systems like bridges, highways, and foundations function and interact with environmental conditions.
Use civil engineering software and methods (e.g., AutoCAD, STAAD.Pro, SAP2000) to solve problems related to design and analysis.
Examine structural systems and material performance to identify stress points, stability issues, and areas for improvement.
Assess the feasibility, sustainability, and safety of proposed civil engineering projects considering environmental impact and codes.
Design a sustainable civil infrastructure project or model—such as a smart road, green building, or water management system.
Recall fundamental terms and biological principles relevant to bioengineering, such as cell biology, tissue engineering, and biomechanics.
Explain how bioengineering systems like prosthetics, biosensors, and imaging technologies function within biological contexts.
Use mathematical, biological, and engineering principles to solve problems related to biomedical device design and physiological modeling.
Break down complex bio-systems and medical devices to study interactions, component behavior, and system-level performance.
Assess the safety, effectiveness, and regulatory compliance of biomedical products or interventions based on real-world data and standards.
Design an innovative bioengineering solution such as a biocompatible implant, tissue scaffold, or diagnostic tool to meet healthcare needs.
Recall basic principles, terminology, and units used in chemical processes such as thermodynamics, kinetics, and material balances.
Explain the function of unit operations like distillation, heat exchangers, and reactors within chemical process systems.
Apply mass and energy balance equations to solve engineering problems in areas such as separation processes or reactor design.
Interpret process flow diagrams and analyze system behavior to identify inefficiencies, safety risks, or design flaws.
Critically assess the sustainability, safety, and economic viability of chemical manufacturing processes and technologies.
Design a chemical process or product—such as a biofuel production unit or waste treatment system—that meets environmental and industrial goals.
Recall fundamental concepts and terminology in management, marketing, finance, operations, and organizational behavior.
Explain how different business functions interact to achieve organizational objectives and contribute to value creation.
Use business frameworks, financial models, and marketing tools to solve real-world management problems.
Interpret financial statements, market trends, and organizational behavior to identify problems and opportunities.
Assess business strategies and decisions using criteria such as profitability, risk, ethics, and sustainability.
Develop a comprehensive business plan, marketing strategy, or financial model that solves a complex business challenge.
Recall core concepts and terminology in circuit theory, electromagnetics, digital electronics, and electrical machines.
Explain the operation of electrical and electronic systems including AC/DC machines, power systems, and embedded systems.
Use simulation tools like MATLAB, Simulink, or PSPICE to model and solve electrical circuit and control system problems.
Examine circuits and systems to determine parameters such as impedance, efficiency, losses, and stability under different conditions.
Critically evaluate the performance and safety of electrical systems based on industry standards and sustainability metrics.
Design and prototype electrical or embedded systems such as smart meters, inverters, or IoT-enabled control systems.
